tools.name: Circular Orbit Design
tools.description: Creates a perfectly circular orbit at specified altitude and inclination. Used for standard orbital configurations like ISS, GPS, and geostationary satellites.

altitude_km.description: Altitude above Earth's surface in kilometers (height of the orbit)

inclination_deg.description: Orbital inclination in degrees (0 = equatorial, 90 = polar)

tools.name: Elliptical Orbit Design
tools.description: Creates an elliptical orbit with specified periapsis (lowest point) and apoapsis (highest point). Used for specialized orbits like Molniya, Hohmann transfers, or highly eccentric communication satellites.

periapsis_km.description: Lowest altitude above Earth's surface in kilometers

apoapsis_km.description: Highest altitude above Earth's surface in kilometers

inclination_deg.description: Orbital inclination in degrees (0 = equatorial, 90 = polar)

tools.name: Clear Workspace
tools.description: Clears the current orbital trajectory from the visualization, providing a clean workspace for designing a new orbit. Implements the single-orbit-at-a-time philosophy.

tools.name: Set Simulation Time Speed
tools.description: Controls how fast TIME flows in the simulation (NOT orbital velocity). 1x = real-time, 10x = 10 simulation seconds per real second. Use when user explicitly mentions 'simulation', 'time acceleration', or uses multiplier format like '5x'.

speed_multiplier.description: Time multiplier: 1 = real-time, 10 = 10x faster time flow, 50 = 50x faster

tools.name: Pause or Resume Simulation
tools.description: Pauses time (freeze everything) or resumes simulation. Use when user says 'pause', 'freeze', 'stop', 'resume', 'unpause', 'continue'.

pause.description: true to pause/freeze, false to resume/continue

tools.name: Reset Mission Clock
tools.description: Resets mission elapsed time to 00:00:00. Use when user wants to restart the timer.

tools.name: Route to Mission Specialist
tools.description: Route user to a Mission Space to explore historical missions and learn from real-world examples. Use when: (1) user explicitly asks about ISS, GPS, Voyager, or Hubble missions, (2) user asks vague questions that need concrete examples (e.g., 'what's a good altitude?'), (3) user is exploring and would benefit from seeing actual mission configurations, (4) user seems stuck on design choices and needs inspiration. Mission Spaces show pre-built orbits that cannot be modified - they are for learning and understanding only.

mission.description: Which mission specialist to connect with: ISS (LEO observation), GPS (MEO constellation), Voyager (interplanetary escape), Hubble (LEO telescope)

context_for_specialist.description: Brief context (1-2 sentences) explaining WHY user is being routed. This helps the specialist tailor their introduction and guidance. Examples: 'wants to understand LEO observation altitudes', 'struggling with inclination choices', 'curious about GPS constellation design', 'exploring interplanetary trajectories'

tools.name: Return to Mission Control Hub
tools.description: Return user to Mission Control Hub from a Mission Space. Use when user expresses desire to leave the current mission, go back to hub, return to mission control, or is done exploring the current mission. The Hub is where users can create custom orbits and access all simulation controls.

GEO.description: Geostationary orbit (stays above same point on equator)

Molniya.description: Russian communication satellite orbit (8-hour dwell over northern hemisphere)

Polar.description: Polar orbit for Earth observation (covers entire planet)
